Claims were made by KGI Securities analyst Ming-Chi Kuo during a note to investors on Tuesday. He said the next-generation iPhone will feature Force Touch, recently added to the Apple Watch and new MacBook. Force Touch recognises typical scrolling and pinching gestures, but additionally tracks the pressure of a click. This means gestures and tracking feel more intuitive and are more responsive. It follows recent rumours which suggested a 4-inch version of the iPhone 6 is in development to replace the iPhone 5C .
Rebecca Sedwick leaped to her death from the roof of an abandoned concrete plant in Lakeland, Florida in September 2013. The following month, the Polk County Sheriff's Office said she likely killed herself following 'malicious harassment' from two schoolmates, Katelyn Roman, 12, and Guadalupe Shaw, 13. Both girls were arrested on charges of aggravated stalking and the sheriff's office distributed their names and mug shots. But the charges were dropped when police were unable to find any evidence of harassment. One of the girls has now filed a lawsuit.
Palaeontologists at the University of Alberta examined a pair of fossils found in Mongolia. One is a complete skeleton, while the other is missing the middle and end of its tail. They found signs of sexual dimorphism in the length and shape of blade-like bones called chevrons, which point downwards from the vertebrae near the base of the tail. Male oviraptorosaurs shook their tail feathers to woo potential mates .

People with rapid eye movement sleep behaviour disorder (RBD) move around in their sleep and 'act out' their dreams. Up to 90 per cent of people with RBD will develop Parkinson's disease or another neurological condition. RBD is not curable, but it can be treated with high doses of sleep aid or low doses of the anti-anxiety drug.

Anti-Islam protesters clashed with anti-racism activists in Melbourne yesterday. Police were forced to separate the groups after clashes turned ugly and several people were injured. 16 rallies were scheduled to take place across Australia, but Sydney and Melbourne drew the biggest crowds. The protests came as companies seeking to label their foods halal must pay fees to Islamic organisations for inspection and certification of food products  .

The old woman tried to chase after the young boy, but soon after there was a loud scream as he fell into the drainage ditch. His father searched for the boy's body but it took him 15 minutes to find his son. Emergency workers spent almost an hour trying to resuscitate him.

Between Friday and Sunday 5,629 migrants were picked up in the Sicilian Channel. Italy is the first port of call for migrants seeking new lives in Europe. 160,000 made the journey last year, often on unseaworthy and overcrowded vessels. Nine bodies recovered after boat capsized.

Iraqi forensic teams began excavating 12 mass graves today on Saddam Hussein's presidential compound. They are believed to be the final resting place of as many as 1,700 soldiers killed by ISIS last summer. The soldiers were slaughtered by Sunni militants for the 'crime' of being Shi'ite. Families have been left wondering what became of them.

The Eco Experts has created maps plotting which countries have the most threatened mammals. The maps were designed by London-based The Eco Experts using the World Bank's World Development Indicator for Deforestation and biodiversity figures. Indonesia sits at the top of the list because deforestation in the region is leaving many species at risk. Madagascar is second, with 114 endangered mammals, while Mexico sits in third with 101 and India in fourth.

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) affects one in three women, making it twice as common as thrush. It occurs when the balance of internal bacteria is disrupted, leading to an unpleasant odour. Pregnant women with the condition are six times more likely to miscarry and twice as likely to give birth prematurely.

The map reveals average yearly counts of lightning flashes per square kilometre from 1995 to 2013. It was created using data from Nasa’s Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission satellite and Orbview-1/Microlab satellite. Highest amounts of lightning occur in the far eastern Democratic Republic of Congo and Lake Maracaibo in northwestern Venezuela. Areas with the fewest number of flashes each year are grey and purple .

Germ line genetic editing alters the DNA in sperm and egg cells - meaning the changes can be passed on to future generations. Scientists fear it could be misused to allow parents to 'select' the genes they will pass on to their grandchildren. But others argue that the technology could also be used to rid families of devastating inherited diseases like cystic fibrosis.

This includes an ambitious project to launch spacecraft and probes into orbit from a huge carrier aircraft with a wingspan of 385ft (117 metres) The plane will climb to 30,000 feet and launch a rocket at high altitude, avoiding the huge fuel costs of launching from Earth. Fanuc's robot uses integrated vision technology called iRVision to keep an eye on humans and automatically stops if it touches an operator. This removes the need for safety fences - a previous requirement for all industrial robots. The robot can lift objects weighing up to 77 lbs (35kg) and could be used in a number of industries, from warehouses to production lines  .

Spotted on April 19 last year, researchers used camera footage to help recreate its trajectory and hunt down any remaining fragments. They determined the fireball's path by studying its flight and the meteorite's final impact site. This led researchers to the Annama meteorite, which is an ordinary H5 chondrite - a group of space rocks with high strength that make up 31 per cent of meteorite falls.

Grenada is known for its zesty spices and self-sufficiency - the only food it imports is milk. Rosemary spent a week on the island, where fresh foodstuffs like cocoa fruit are easily available .
Bogan Shire Council, in western New South Wales, wants to erect a 'big bogan' statue in Nyngan. Graeme Burke is the manager of engineering services for the council. The 3.6-metre statue would show a 'bloke' wearing shorts, thongs and a singlet with a fishing rod and a tuckerbox. Locals and visitors would be able to sit on it and take photographs . Local residents have expressed mixed feelings about it.

Ricky Dearman said his reputation was shattered after being branded leader of a London satanic cult. He was falsely accused of masterminded the trafficking of children into the UK to be tortured and killed. Scotland Yard investigated the 'baseless' claims but found they had been made by his children. Police are now hunting for Ella Draper and her partner Abraham Christie, who may have fled abroad. Mr Dearman now hopes to win custody of his children, who are eight and nine and currently in care .
Britain will still be running a budget deficit at the end of the decade despite plans to return the country to the black. The International Monetary Fund said the state will continue to spend more on public services. The projection underlines just how hard it will be to eliminate the country's annual deficit .
Wonga, the UK’s biggest payday loans firm, today revealed it racked up a £37.3million loss last year. Revenues declined to £217.2million in the period, down by almost £100million. City watchdog predicts just three or four lenders will survive.
Vincent Cianni, 63, spent three years traveling the U.S. photographing and interviewing gay veterans and servicemen to share their stories of suppression, sadness and silence in a moving photo essay. The photos show commonalities between the subjects despite their different journeys, from a 92-year-old WW2 veteran to young soldiers who recently returned from Afghanistan. Many were discharged because of their sexuality.

Police are worried about the welfare of the five children believed to be with the couple. The couple left the house several weeks or months ago, leaving the 17-year old girl with the two younger children in a brown stucco home.

It derailed after apparently hitting a tree that had fallen onto the tracks shortly after 8.30pm on Friday. Derailment caused up to 15 cars to overturn and leak, sparking a 1.5-mile-wide evacuation.

This was seven times higher than France’s 0.4 per cent, according to an International Monetary Fund report. Britain is expected to cement its position in the coming years as one of the fastest growing major economies in the West .

There is a rising number of firms in the US that sell dog and cat biscuits containing cannabidiol, or CBD, taken from hemp. Compounds in the plant have been known to alleviate joint pains, treat mood disorders and help pets lose weight. Research has also suggested CBD can relieve pain and discomfort in dying pets and calm animals down. Canna Companion, based in Sultan in Washington, uses hemp from the Cannabis sativa strain in its capsules and biscuits for both cats and dogs  .

The interview comes just days after Bates turned himself in to face charges of second-degree manslaughter and was released on bond.
The new map allows astronomers to 'stand' on planetary surfaces and could help explain how water and lava once flowed across Mars. The first mosaic, pieced together by the German Aerospace Center (DLR), comprises 1.4 million square miles (2.3 million square km) of the surface. It covers the vast crater-strewn highland region of the red planet, parts of the Ares Vallis.

The laws include fining agencies employing models with a BMI under 18 and criminalising pro-anorexia web content. But Rachel Cole-Fletcher, of Durham University, says it is not a lifestyle choice and personality traits are to blame. She says the laws may be unlikely to have any such effect .

Among the reasons given were that overweight workers 'are unable to play a full role in the business' European judges ruled in December obesity qualified as a disability if it 'hinders the full and effective participation of the person... on an equal basis with other workers' .

University of Cologne scientist led research proposing a new theory. It suggests temperatures at Earth's equator were -40°C (-40°F) 2.4 billion years ago. The reasons why the whole planet was frozen are not understood. But it could have implications for finding life on frozen moons like Europa and Enceladus. This theory can also help explain a period in Earth’s history known as the Great Oxygen Transition. Here, oxygen levels began to rapidly rise from 0% to 21%.

Ministry of Defence 1, also known as ‘Churchill’s Toyshop’, was a weapons laboratory set up in 1939 by Winston Churchill. He encouraged his scientists to trial even the most absurd of inventions. Some were so successful they ended World War Two.
The TrackYourDose app was developed by Germany-based firm esooka. It uses a mathematical model developed by scientists and meteorologists. The £1.49 ($1.99) iOS app keeps a record of a user's personal radiation. This includes exposure from medical examinations, changes in a person's location and flights. It also tracks cosmic radiation from air travel and cosmic radiation on the ground. The app can measure all the relevant types of radiation, in particular neutron radiation produced in the atmosphere .
Lloyd Byfield, 48, pursued a relationship with 26-year-old Leighann Duffy before killing her in Walthamstow, London. He attacked her with a claw hammer and a kitchen knife in front of her daughter, six. Judge Nicholas Cooke told him he must have had a 'heart of stone' to have killed Ms Duffy. He was sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 26-and-a-half years for murder. Judge Cooke also expressed his 'unhappiness' at the failure of authorities to deport Byfield back to Jamaica. He said murder could have been prevented if he had been sent to Jamaica in 2005 .

Nasa scientists in California have released new images of Ceres. They were taken by the Dawn spacecraft from a distance of 21,000 miles (33,000km) The spacecraft is beginning to move closer and closer to the dwarf planet. And it will soon study the whole planet - including its mystery bright spots. The images have not yet revealed what the mystery ‘bright spots’ on the surface of Ceres are. They are thought to be volcanoes or volcanoes, but could have different properties.

The question, 'So when is Cheryl’s birthday?' was one of 25 questions set in the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad. Cheryl gives them a list of 10 possible dates: May 15, May 16, May 19, June 17, June 18, July 14, July 16, August 14, August 15 and August 17. Cheryl then tells Albert and Bernard separately the month and day of her birthday respectively. Each of the men does not know what the other has been told .

Gold Sachs predicts population growth will slow to 1.25 per cent over the next three years due to low birth rates, high death rates and falling net migration. Property prices are predicted to fall by up to 10 per cent in some states with economists tipping a housing surplus in 2017. The report predicts Australia's population will be 530,000.

Flow VR provides passengers with a virtual image of the horizon that mimics the movements of the aircraft. This can help to combat the conflict between the information coming from a person's eyes and their sense of balance in the inner ear, which can lead to travel sickness. Device was created by British company Flow IFE .

Stormy weather system,  formed in the Tasman Sea, hasn't hit NSW this strong since 2007. East Coast Lows are characterised by gales or storm force winds that can damage buildings, fell trees and powerlines. They can also dump hundreds of millimetres of rain, causing flash flooding and riverine flooding. An estimated 100,000 homes are without power on Tuesday morning across Sydney, the Central Coast and Hunter region. Ferry services have been cancelled at Parramatta.

Researchers at the University of Sheffield analysed people with a body mass index of 30 or more. They found obese people fall into one of six categories:. 'Heavy drinking males' showed similar characteristics, but consumed a high level of alcohol. 'Younger healthy females' were the group most likely to display positive health characteristics. 'Physically sick but happy elderly' had a higher prevalence of chronic health problems including high blood pressure and above average alcohol consumption.
Psychologists from Goldsmiths University of London, and Ohio State University in the US studied more than 13,000 twins aged nine to 16 from six countries. They found that 40 to 50 per cent of the differences in children’s motivation to learn could be explained by their genetic inheritance from their parents. The researchers said they were surprised by the results, believing that the twins’ shared environment would be a larger factor.

Nasa scientists in California have revealed new images of the dwarf planet Ceres. They reveal new views of the two brightest spots in a crater. However, scientists are still not able to explain what they are. Several theories currently exist for what they might be, with the favoured being salt flats or ice - both reflecting sunlight. Dawn will begin its first science orbit around Ceres on 23 April. There is high interest in the mission because Ceres is seen as being a record of the early solar system, and may have shifting ice.
Swiss researchers measured the temperature of 'Hot Jupiter' HD 189733b. They found the temperature reaches up to 3,000°C in the atmosphere of the planet. And wind speeds are in excess of 620mph (1,000km/h) The findings were made using a novel technique relying on sodium signals. The technique works by measuring the ‘sodium signal’ from distant worlds. When a planet passes in front of its star, the intensity of this signal varies. Depending on how weak or strong the signal is, it is possible to work out how hot the planet is   .

First identified in 2000, Jerusalem syndrome is characterised by anxiety, agitation and nervousness. Sufferers are often consumed by a need to be clean, before donning a toga-like gown. The next stage sees sufferers overcome by the need to scream, or sing out loud psalms, verses from the Bible or religious hymns.

UK researchers studied the asteroid impact 66 million years ago. They found the heat near the impact site in Mexico was not intense enough to ignite plant material. A heat pulse lasted less than a minute, too short to set plants alight. It suggests our understanding of the mass extinction event that wiped out the dinosaurs may not be as complete as thought. The core they hope to retrieve will allow them to look back in time 10 million to 15 million years into the past.

A series of bronze artefacts were found at the 'Rising Whale' site in Cape Espenberg, Alaska. Bronze-working had not been developed at this time in Alaska, and researchers believe they were created in China, Korea or Yakutia. Bronze artefacts give the best evidence to date that non-ferrous industrial smelted metals were arriving in Alaska via prehistoric trade across the Bering Strait  .

In the 1930s, Yaphank, Long Island was a haven for Americans who sympathized with the causes of the Third Reich. It was largely founded as a Nazi camp, one of several scattered across the U.S., where the children in the German American Bund (AKA American Nazis) could fish, swim, hunt and learn about eugenics. The FBI and New York police kept close tabs on the Bund in the town in the run-up to America joining the Allies in 1941 .

Chlorine gas was carried by favourable winds over Flanders Fields from German positions on April 22, 1915. Some 1,200 French soldiers were killed in the chaos of that first five-minute gas attack. 'It is a new element in warfare. It is indiscriminate,' said Piet Chielens, curator at the In Flanders Field Museum. On Tuesday the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons will hold a commemorative meeting .

The storm formed in the worst possible spot, just north of Newcastle. It then covered 150km south from Newcastle to Wollongongong where a third of Australia’s population live. Researchers have found that bird species are continuing to drop in Fukushima. The barn swallow, for example, dropped from hundreds to dozens. This is despite radiation levels in the region starting to fall. And comparing it to Chernobyl could reveal what the future holds. One of the most hard-hit species is the barn swallow which suffered large population losses due to radiation exposure  .

Number of hayfever sufferers in UK predicted to reach 20 million this summer, up a third from last year. Five million people are expected to fall victim to the symptoms, which include streaming eyes, incessant sneezing and irritating itches at the back of the throat for the first time. By 2030, there will be 31.8 million sufferers as the situation will worsen, according to leading pollen expert Dr Jean Emberlin.

He is the lone officer among 13 who fired their weapons that night who is charged criminally because prosecutors say he stood on the hood and opened fire four seconds after the other officers had stopped shooting. Primatologists at Iowa State University recorded 300 hunts by chimps in Fongoli, Sénégal, Senegal. They found female chimps were using tools to capture prey in 60 per cent of the observations. However, the male chimpanzees tended to capture larger prey and used their hands. The research may also provide tantalising hints at how humans first learned to use weapons to hunt. It suggests that early female humans were perhaps the first to begin fashioning simple tools to help them catch prey.
Robin Wright won Best Actress for her role in House of Cards at the Golden Globes last night. She wore a golden dress from Reem Acra's Fall 2013 collection and looked stunning in it. She and Sean Penn divorced in 2010 after nearly 20 years of marriage. They have two children together .
Molly Schuyler won the 72-ounce steak dinner challenge at the Big Texan Steak Ranch restaurant in Amarillo, Texas on Sunday. The 120-pound mother-of-four ate three steaks, three shrimp cocktails, three baked potatoes, three salads and three rolls for a total of 15 pounds .
Restaurateurs in the country are so angry with the US corporation for attacking their cultural diet they have said they will take them to court. Top pizza chef described the advert as 'blasphemy'  .
KFC allowed hundreds of people to tour the back of 219 stores across Australia and roam from freezer to fryer on Saturday. The fast food giant hoped to dispel myths around the quality and freshness of their ingredients and prove their chicken was fresh and cooked in the kitchen of each store. The George Institute for Global Health warned consumers not to equate KFC's attempt to build customer trust through displaying respectable food safety standards.

Castle Toward, near Dunoon, was commissioned as HMS Brontosaurus in 1942. Overlooking the Clyde estuary and with easy access to the sloping shoreline, it was ideal training ground. Soldiers practised beach landings - complete with bombs, smokescreens and strafing fighters - jumping from landing craft and clambering up.

At least half a million Britons suffer from sleep apnoea - a condition often typified by heavy snoring. The onset of Alzheimer's might be accelerated among those with sleeping problems.

Carwyn Scott-Howell plunged 160ft to his death in Flaine, France, while skiing with his family. State prosecutor Pierre Yves Michau ruled out negligence as a factor in his death. Family expected to bring his body home this weekend .
The Crowd Source collection holds around 150 photographs taken by Arthur Syer, a 27-year-old man living in Sydney who took advantage of the very first hand held camera, the Detective Camera. The detective camera was produced between 1883 and 1887 using a dry negative which was already loaded into the device. It was loaded, focused and ready to take a photograph at around six feet away. The images were collected over a period of time and were originally released on Flickr.

Since its construction in 1895, Holmesburg Prison has housed some of the country's most dangerous criminals. In 2011, haunting images emerged showing the aftermath of cruel chemical experiments carried out on inmates. Prisoners were paid to test dangerous substances such as radioactive, hallucinogenic and toxic materials. Since its closure in 1996, the prison's halls have fallen eerily silent .

Chris Rowe, 31, was plagued by a persistent cough for six months. He visited doctors five times in two months but was told he was most likely suffering a virus. But after noticing a dull ache in his ribs and coughing up blood, he was taken to A&E. An X-ray revealed a tumour on his lung and he was diagnosed with lung cancer in December. The cancer had spread to his liver and bones and is inoperable. He is undergoing gruelling rounds of chemotherapy in a bid to prolong his life. His wife Kate, 28, is due to give birth to their second child in June.

Security research firm Bitglass created an excel spreadsheet of 1,568 fake employee credentials. It was placed on anonymous file sharing sites within the Dark Web, using a Tor browser as an entry point. The data was viewed more than 1,000 times and downloaded 47 times. Some activity had connections to crime syndicates in Nigeria and Russia. Traffic patterns suggest the fake data was shared among members of the syndicates.

Jafar Adeli, 32, arranged to meet someone he believed to be a 14-year-old girl for sex on the internet. But he was arrested by police when he turned up at a bus station in Leicester with three condoms in his pocket. Adeli had been duped by paedophile vigilante group Letzgo Hunting who filmed the meeting . He was jailed for 27 months after admitting attempting to meet a girl under 16 for grooming .

Young was jailed for 18 years after admitting attempted murder at Newcastle Crown Court. Miss Bolton was left scarred for life and needed more than 100 stitches to her face, arms and body  .

Daughter Claire, 21, made £26,180 and sister Caitlyn, 19, £7,476 from their illegal enterprise. Their company 'Designer Goods North East' took more than £7,000 in online payments in just four months. One daughter boasted of making £100 a week and said she dreamed of going it alone  .

The tiny copper coin, which is smaller than a penny, dates from the Iron Age almost 2,300 years ago. It was found in silt after the River Avon burst its banks between Bristol and Bath. Experts have dated the coin to between 300 BC and 264 BC and say it came from the Western Mediterranean. It suggests links between the south west of England and the Mediterranean long before Roman times .
The 18-year-old daughter of actor Stephen Baldwin stars in a new shoot for the May issue of Elle magazine. She is known for her close friendship with fellow fashion star Kendall Jenner  .
Tamoxifen is the main hormonal therapy drug given to women who have not been through the menopause. It blocks the hormone oestrogen from reaching the cancer cells. Study found caffeine caused breast cancer cells to divide less frequently and die more often.
New approach will target cancer stem cells that evade conventional drugs and cause tumours to re-grow. Cancer that has spread and is incurable kills 1,000 women in Britain every month. Researchers from Manchester University working with drug development company Evgen.
You need to eat just ten almonds to get your daily requirement of calcium (700mg) Two Brazil nuts provide 100% of our daily required dose of selenium. Cashews are a good source of iron.

Airline Visual Identity 1945-1975 revisits a time when the skies were dominated by the likes of Pan Am, British Overseas Airways Corp (BOAC) and Continental. The 436-page book contains dozens of glamorous adverts that encouraged those who could afford to fly to visit far-flung destinations such as Haiti, Hawaii and Japan.
Jason Warnock, 29, was driving Wednesday morning in Lewiston, Idaho when he saw debris near the road and looked up to see a vehicle crashed into a chain-link fence on the edge of a cliff. He then parked his car, ran up a pedestrian footbridge and pulled driver Matthew Sitko, 23, out to safety. Since he didn't stop to give police his name, Warnock remained a mystery for nearly 24 hours as the photo of the self-less rescue went viral online. Police say Sitko had just dropped off his younger siblings at school when a song came on in the vehicle and it 'convinced him to die'

Wylie Brys and his dad, Dallas zookeeper Tim Brys, were digging for fossils near a construction site near a Mansfield, Texas, grocery store when Wylie found the dinosaur bones. It's believed the bones belong to a nodosaur, a pony-sized herbivore with scaly, plated skin that dwelled on land in the area.

Eve Addison, now 24, developed strange swelling in her collarbone after drinking gin and tonic. She assumed she must have an allergy, but when switching brands failed to help she saw her GP. Tests revealed 24-year-old was suffering Hodgkin Lymphoma - cancer of the lymphatic system. Most common symptom of Hodgkin lymphoma is one or more painless swellings in the neck, armpit or groin .

Coroner will write to Government chiefs to ask why swimming is not included in secondary school education. Swimming is compulsory during primary school but not enforced for those aged 11 or over. Headteacher said Rony was eligible for six lessons a year.
Lidia Quilligana was arrested in Danbury, Connecticut last month after police viewed a video that allegedly showed her choking and beating a 3-year-old girl. She was also caught allegedly burning the legs, arms and hands of the girl on a hot stove as she screamed out in pain. This after the girl's family set up a nanny cam thinking that something was happening to the girl. Her bail has been set at $1million and she will appear in court April 22.
Pictures were taken by the Stasi - the Ministry for State Security - during the 40 year existence of the East German state. They were used as evidence in the show trials against people caught trying to escape the Communist regime. The pictures were also thought to have been used for training purposes for border guards and trainee agents. Photographer Arwed Messmer found the pictures in the archives of the secret police .

Scientists at Brandeis University in Massachusetts believe memory neurons that are responsible for converting short-term memories into long-term ones, work most effectively when a person is asleep. They focused their research on dorsal paired medial neurons, well-known memory consolidators.

The USS Oklahoma capsized after being hit by nine torpedoes during the December 7, 1941, surprise attack from Japanese forces. Altogether, 429 sailors and Marines onboard were killed, but only 35 were identified . Hundreds were buried as unknowns at cemeteries in Hawaii until 1950, when they were reburied . Pentagon announced Tuesday plans to exhume and try to identify remains of up to 388 servicemen .

Last year in South Africa 1,215 rhinos were poached and killed - one every eight hours. Poachers are looking to sell rhino horn which can make up to £47,000 a kilo. Rhino horn is made from keratin, the same stuff as fingernails, and is used to treat blood disorders. People will pay an absurd amount for an absurd product because of an absurd belief: that rhino Horn is the most wonderful kind of medicine.

Activision Blizzard has announced plans to resurrect the popular video game franchise later this year. Called Guitar Hero Live, the revamped game features a redesigned guitar, live-action actors and an online music video network. It will cast players as an up-and-coming guitarist in a fictitious band. Instead of playing along with computer-generated characters, players will see a first-person view of their band and audiences portrayed by human actors. The game will be released in the autumn for the PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360.

Experts from Centre for International Research in the Humanities and Social Sciences (CIRHUS) in New York City studied neolithic ornaments to understand how farming spread. Airline Codes lists the origins of 438 airport codes from 94 countries. The codes are known as IATA location identifiers, and are set by the International Air Transport Association. Many airports change names over the years so their airport codes might reflect a previous identity or purpose .

Facebook’s Sidebar status feature will let users post a short message about what they are doing in a sidebar added to the social network's mobile app, complete with an illustrative picture. The feature is currently only available to selected people for testing in Taiwan and Australia. Users can choose from an array of small pictures, such as a bicycle or coffee cup, to go with their status and add a location tag.

Study looked at the voting habits of 2,355 twins born in the UK in March 2015. The aim was to explore how much nature and nurture influence our party political allegiances. They found identical twins were more likely to vote the same way than non-identical twins. This suggests an underlying genetic influence was stronger than environmental or random factors. For UKIP voting preferences, there was also a moderately strong heritability of 51 per cent. This was closely followed by Labour and the Green Party both with 48 per cent  .
Skelet dating to between the 5th and 6th century seems to hold remains of two lovers. Skeletons were found on top of one another in the tomb from Korea’s Silla Dynasty. Experts say the set-up could even have been designed to show two people having sex. It's thought the tomb was intended for a noblewoman and the man may have been killed to be buried with her .

London-based designer Crispin Sinclair claims to have made the world's safest bike. Called the Babel Bike it has a host of features including a roll cage. The bike also has foot protectors and an electric motor that assists it at speeds of up to 20mph. Crispin is seeking £50,000 ($74,000) of funding on site Indiegogo .
Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - our distant ancestors - to move to new regions. The theory is based on analysis of the Barranco León site in the Guadix-Baza Basin in Spain. Simple Oldowan tools have previously been found at the site. But they were not able to migrate to this region until conditions improved, allowing them to scavenge carcasses.
Ashley Madison, an online dating agency, is betting on Europe's relaxed attitude to boost its investment when it lists shares on the stock market in London later this year. It's founder Noel Biderman, 43, who came up with the idea for the site in the 1990s when he worked as a sports attorney. He wants to raise money from investors to fund a launch of its services in Russia, Ukraine and the Baltic states .

The tunnels were dug into sandstone cliffs along the River Mersey in Stockport in the 1930s. They were originally intended to provide car parking spaces, but were redeveloped as an air raid shelter. The Optimal case was designed by Israel-based Amited. Sensors in the case monitor the phone's temperature and if it gets too hot, Optimal will cool it down. It uses micro-fans to blow heat away from the device, or can heat a phone using resistance coils. Optimal syncs with a smartphone over Bluetooth and constantly analyses temperature. Users can also manually track temperature changes using an app   .

Study was conducted by scientists at Purdue University in Indiana and the National Wildlife Research Centre in Ohio. They were investigating how to reduce bird to aircraft collisions by keeping birds away from planes. Research showed that birds responded most to blue lights on planes. When the plane was stationary, the birds became alert more quickly when the lights were on. But when it approached them with its lights off, their response slowed. And the birds were also more likely to get out of the way of the aircraft when lights were pulsing, rather than continuous.
Ronnie Carroll died just days after getting on General Election ballot paper for Hampstead and Kilburn. Due to stand as an independent, Mr Carroll was 80 and had contested elections before. He died following a battle with cancer, during which a friend handed in his nomination papers as he was ill.

The disturbing clips showed Australian shearers kicking, stamping and mutilating the creatures before stitching up their butchered wounds with a needle. The system would allow machines to download them in a similar way to an app - and even have a different personality for each user. Scientists at Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital have developed a device that clips onto the smartphone. It uses the powerful cameras available now on most smartphones in combination with tiny beads that bind to cancerous cells. When clumped around a cell, the beads alter the way the light passes through the sample. Using a smartphone app, these images can then be sent to a central computer for analysis. The result can be returned in less than 45 minutes .

Study uncovered a link between belief in God and other societal characteristics, such as a strong social hierarchy. Scientists suggest that religious beliefs help people cope in inhospitable habitats. Communities that believe in a high, controlling God or gods who enforce a moral code, tend to live in politically complex groups with a social hierarchy beyond the local community.

The female, named Varvara, swam 14,000 miles (22,500km) from the east coast of Russia to breeding grounds off the coast of Mexico, and back, without even stopping for a snack when she was nine years old. Her return journey across the North Pacific raises questions about the critically endangered creature’s conservation status. Gray whales typically don't feed during migration, which has led researchers to believe Varvarva didn't eat during the long journey.

A Japanese bullet train has broken the speed record for rail vehicles by reaching 366mph (589km/h) Maglev trains use magnets to lift the carriages above the track. This eliminates the need for wheels and therefore any incidence of friction, providing a faster and quieter service. The technology promises a ride that's smoother, quieter and almost twice as fast as traditional high-speed rail. The new line between Tokyo and Nagoya comes into service in 2027.

The 17,000-square-foot estate in Vail Valley, Colorado, was built in 2008 by Dick Rothkopf, a former toy company chief. It took two years, a team of engineers and $1 million to build the 1.5-mile driveway from the roadway to its front door. The property, known as 'Il Podere', means 'family homestead' in Italian, has eight bedrooms and eight full bathrooms .
Michael Easy, 29, from Southampton, Hampshire, went on the run in 2013 after attacking a woman at a party. He sparked a nationwide police manhunt and posted photos of himself on Facebook posing in a wig and sunglasses. He was jailed for 15 months after assaulting his former girlfriend when she was pregnant with his child. He has now been jailed for breaching a restraining order again.
Kathy Ferreiro, 21, has been dubbed the 'Cuban Kim Kardashian' by the Miami fashion crowd. The Miami-based Latina is well known for strutting her stuff on the region's balmy beaches and loves to pose for selfies .
Leo Schofield, 79, claimed living in Tasmania was the unhappiest time of his life. He moved to Hobart to set up a Baroque music festival in what he claims was an attempt to help Tasmanians take advantage of the state's grand heritage. He decided to relocate back to New South Wales after the Tasmanian Government cut the festivals funding by 25 per cent   .
The former Obama administration official endorsed gay marriage in 2013 after she left the State Department, saying she 'was fully in support of gay marriage' Now a presidential candidate, Clinton today gave same-sex marriage her complete backing ahead of the presentation later this month of oral arguments in several cases before the Supreme Court on the matter. The shift puts Clinton's views in line with the Obama administration's Justice Department, which in January 'committed to ensuring that the benefits of marriage are available as broadly as possible'
Shah Jahah Khan, 62, and Muslim convert Ibrahim Anderson, 38, both from Luton, each deny one charge of inviting support for a banned organisation. The pair are accused of setting up a stall on London's Oxford Street and handing out ISIS propaganda leaflets. Both pleaded not guilty to terror offences today .
Florida mailman Doug Hughes, 61, landed his gyro-copter on the West Front lawn of the US Capitol on Wednesday afternoon. House Homeland Security Chairman Michael McCaul revealed that Capitol authorities were prepared to open fire on the craft if it got any closer to the speaker's balcony. Hughes claims he informed the Secret Service and Capitol police of his potentially lethal stunt into the no-fly zone, which was designed to draw attention to campaign finance reform and government corruption. NORAD reported that they did not scramble any assets and were not informed of the flight until it had landed. Hughes was promptly arrested by police and FBI teams moved in quickly afterwards.
The eight-year-old girl who died in a horrific accident in New South Wales has been identified as Piper. She was in the car with her two brothers, her mother and grandmother when the accident happened. The young girl's grandmother, Helen Boddy, was also in the vehicle at the time of the accident on Saturday. Two boys, aged nine and 12, were airlifted to The Children's Hospital at Westmead in a critical condition .

Italian astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti wore the uniform on Friday. Together with Nasa astronaut Terry Virts she captured the spacecraft. On board it had 4,000lbs of supplies - including a coffee machine. It will remain at the ISS for a month before returning to Earth. It is the California-based SpaceX company's seventh station supply run since 2012, all from Cape Canaveral. The ISS has now been in space for more than 5,900 days, during which time it has completed more than 92,000 orbits of Earth. This mission carried with it a treat for the astronauts - a specially designed machine called the ISSPresso. It uses a 'capsule system' to fill plastic pouches with espresso.

Research focused on POMC neurons, which are a structure called the hypothalamus. They send and receive signals to regulate appetite. When they are absent, or not working properly, animals and humans grow dangerously obese .

'I shot him enough times to kill him,’ she said, ‘so that he wouldn't suffer... He was laying there, twitching and making noises, and I shot him in the head'

Four men with guns and knives boarded the sailboat and took all of their money. A monster crocodile has been caught devouring a one metre long lizard in one bite at a Northern Territory river. The hungry fresh water crocodile swallowed the lizard whole at the Mary River near Pine Creek. The incident comes just a month after a 4.38 metre croc was caught eating dogs .

Dr Fredric Brandt, a celebrity plastic surgeon, was found hanged in his home on Easter Sunday morning. Friends claim he was upset by his portrayal in Tina Fey's new TV show The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt. Martin Short plays Dr Franff, a white-haired cosmetologist with fillers in his face, who is lampooned in the show. Brandt's friends claim he identified the resemblance and laughed it off, but others say he was 'definitely hurt' by the portrayal. The doctor, who suffered from depression, spent his Saturday nights at home injecting himself in fillers. Police report reveals Brandt was suffering suicidal tendencies for just 10 days before he killed himself, according to a friend  .

He headed the Naqshbandi Order insurgent group, an important faction behind the rise of ISIS. He was one of Saddam's most trusted henchmen, helping to lead his 1968 bloodless coup. Was deputy to Saddam when he was deposed in 2003.
Emmanuel Sithole was brutally attacked in Alexandra township near Johannesburg, South Africa. He was stabbed repeatedly with knives and beaten with a wrench before being left bleeding to death in a gutter. Doctors tried in vain to save his life as medical centre 300 feet away was closed for the day. Victim's cause of death later established as a direct stab wound to the heart and his identity established from mobile phone found in his pocket.

Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS. It would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit. The system would have a range of 62 miles (100km) and could target things less than 0.4 inches (1cm) in size. Powerful pulses from the laser would then push space junk into Earth’s atmosphere, where it would burn up. The paper was published in Acta Astronautica by researchers in Tokyo.

Italian Alex Bellini will live atop an iceberg in Greenland starting next year. He will live inside a contained ball, with no means to escape for 12 months. The capsule will be 10ft (three metres) wide and could fit 10 people - but he will remove all of the seats except one for himself. The aim of the cabin fever-inducing stunt is to highlight how global warming will melt icebergs around the world and cause sea levels to rise. He hopes to begin in November 2016 near Greenland .

Volvo teamed up with a Swedish start-up to make a light reflective spray for cyclists called Life Paint. It contains powder-fine reflective particles designed to react to a car’s headlights. In the dark it reflects light in the same direction as the light source to alert drivers to cyclists in the dark. Can be applied to clothes, helmets, pushchairs, dog leads and even bikes. A trial began in London bike shops on 2 April to gauge public interest and 2,000 cans were given away free.

University of Manchester researchers have revealed an HD dark matter map. It shows clumps of mystery particles across 0.4 per cent of the sky. Red here shows more dark matter, and blue shows less. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 per cent over five years. And the map should allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe. It was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device. The survey uses the 13ft (four metres) Victor M. Blanco Telescope.

Canadian duo Mitchell Moffit and Greg Brown, from Toronto, present online science show AsapSCIENCE on YouTube. They discuss how being the first, middle, youngest, or only child affects us. First-born children are expected to be higher academic achievers and more mature. Middle children tend to be more co-operative, flexible and sociable. Last-borns are charming and confident, they say .
A cloud formation resembling the Wi-Fi symbol appeared recently in the sky of Xiangtan city in Hunan Province. The global symbol has one dot and three curved lines radiating from it in central China.
Kestrel and barn owl repeatedly lunged at each other while trying to gain mastery of the box. The fight was captured on video by wildlife photographer Robert Fuller.
10,000 women a year in the UK are affected by the debilitating hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) Condition causes constant vomiting, crippling weakness and dehydration. Study looked at 312 children born to 203 mothers with HG between 2007 and 2011.
Kyli Wilfson, now 29, was 26 when she first started experiencing agonizing pain in her stomach in October 2012. Doctors initially thought she had acute pancreatitis, a condition that would 'resolve itself' in a matter of days. But the pain continued to return every time she tried to eat, leaving her unable to eat for a year and a half. She was eventually diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis in January 2014.

More than 37 tons have been collected, but there is still an overwhelming stench coming from the lake. Rower and Olympic hopeful Felipe Xavier said: 'I have to come train but these dead fish bother us'

Esa’s Rosetta spacecraft has captured stunning images of a dust jet erupting from comet 67P Churyumov-Gerasimenko. The first image was taken at 7:13am BST on 12 March, and the second was taken two minutes later. The jet is unusual because it is erupted from the dark underside of the comet, whereas such activity had only been seen on the day side so far .

Reddit has placed a clickable button next to a 60-second timer on its r/thebutton thread. When The Button is clicked, the timer resets and it is not yet known what happens when the clock reaches zero. More than 730,285 Reddit users have pressed The Button since the site launched the thread on April Fool's Day. Only people who registered on the site before 1 April are eligible to click The Button. When they do they are awarded a colour, known as a 'flair,' with a number  .

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson has admitted that a gyro-copter flew 80 miles undetected and under the radar from Gettysburg, Pennsylvania to the lawn of the US Capitol on Wednesday. The pilot, Florida postal worker Doug Hughes, was interviewed by the Secret Service almost two years ago. Johnson said his first reaction on hearing of the incident was to ask, 'What's a gyrocopter?' The tiny, open-air aircraft landed without injuries to anyone, but the incident raises questions about how someone could be allowed to fly so far.

Find Boston Bombers was set up by Chris Ryves, known as 'oops777', after the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings. Reddit users posted images and videos of crowds of spectators at the high-profile event. They then used the thread to theorize about the suspect/suspects' identities, based on their demographics. Their claims even led to Sunil Tripathi, a Brown University student who was missing, being wrongly identified as the bomber. Now, Ryves has told of his regrets about the thread - which he says nearly became 'its own beast' - in a new documentary. The Thread will be released on iTunes on Monday .

A 'blob' of warm water 2,000 miles across is sitting in the Pacific Ocean. Since last June it has extended from Alaska to Mexico. It has been present since 2013 and has been causing fish to seek shelter elsewhere. And a new University of Washington study says it could be responsible for droughts. California's drought is one of the worst on record, while the East coast of the US has seen unusually cold temperatures. It is also having an effect on marine life and could be a sign of warmer weather to come.

Llallawavis scagliai was found in a cliff on a beach south of Mar del Plata city in Argentina. It is one of the most complete skeletons of a 'terror bird' - a group of flightless prehistoric meat-eating birds. Scientists used 3D scanning of its skull to examine its hearing ability. They say its hearing was probably below average compared to birds living today  .

People with damage to the right sagittal stratum in the right hemisphere of the brain are unable to detect sarcasm. Stroke survivors often suffer damage to this area of their brain and struggle to recognise when family and friends are being sarcastic. Sarcasm is well known as a complex form of communication as it requires the listener to understand the literal meaning of what someone is saying   .

Estimates suggest around 1,000 iOS apps are vulnerable to a flaw in connectivity software from AFNetworking. This includes Uber, Microsoft's OneDrive and Movies by Flixster. It was first reported at the end of last month by security researchers Simone Bovi and Mauro Gentile. The flaw was active between 24 January until it was flagged up on 25 March. Not all apps and developers use AFNet working, and figures suggest the source code library features on around 100,000 apps in total .

The 18-carat gold Irish Freedom Box was given to Lord Uxbridge in 1828 by Trinity College Dublin. The aristocrat's stoic exchange with the Duke of Wellington after losing his leg has become etched in history. His leg was buried near the battlefield but later dug up and used as a macabre tourist attraction .
Crystal O'Connor, owner of Memories Pizza in Walkerton, Indiana, says she stands by her decision to never cater a gay wedding. She has closed her store, but said she will reopen again and $850,000 has been raised for the pizzeria by supporters in just two days. She said in a recent interview that 'God has blessed us for standing up for what we believe, and not denying him' The news comes just a week after Indiana passed the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which allows businesses to openly discriminate against gays. On Saturday, openly gay basketball stars Jason Collins and Derrick Gordon showed up to watch the NCAA Final Four games in Indianapolis .
In 1992, the Drug Enforcement Agency began secretly tracking phone calls to 116 countries on their watch list for drug trafficking. The program allowed agents to infiltrate drug trafficking rings, especially those previously unknown to the DEA and federal government. It has since been discontinued after nearly two decades.
Michelle Heale of Tom's River, New Jersey, found guilty of killing 14-month-old Mason Hess in August 2012. She claimed she was trying to burp him when he began choking on his applesauce. But when she pulled him off her shoulder his neck snapped backwards, killing the boy. Heale now faces 30 years in prison after being found guilty .
Harvey Weinsten was spotted looking remarkably relaxed and chipper as he stepped outside his New York City townhouse on Thursday. His wife Georgina Chapman has been sharing photos of herself hard at work creating the upcoming Spring/Summer 2016 bridal collection for her brand Marchesa. She was joined by the couple's son Dashiell in the design room on Wednesday. Ambra Battilana, who claims Weinstein groped her during a business meeting, met with prosecutors on Tuesday as a criminal probe into the incident continues but no charges have been filed.
Jourdan Dunn, 24, revealed in an interview that she was severely bullied as a teenager. She was picked on from primary school until secondary school when she had to be home-schooled. The London-born beauty is now the new face of Maybelline New York.
Liverpool striker Mario Balotelli received 8,000 discriminatory posts directed at him. Arsenal's Danny Welbeck received 1,700, 60 per cent of which related to sexual orientation. An abusive message is directed at a Premier League club or one of their players every 2.6 minutes.
A body pulled from the Mississippi River on Saturday has been identified as Barway Edward Collins, 10, who has been missing for nearly a month. Authorities said the body of the ten-year-old was found on Saturday around 1pm by searchers from a Boy Scout troop - about ten feet from the river's edge in Brooklyn Center, Minnesota. Police said on Sunday that the boy's father, Pierre Collins, 33, is a primary suspect as the case becomes a homicide investigation. The case is being considered a homicide based on the autopsy and information from the medical examiner. Barway was last seen riding a bus after school last month .
More than 500,000 people knock on the doors of Abbey Road studios every year, only to be told it is closed to the public. The studios hosted the world's first live global broadcast - from none other than The Beatles - as well as playing a role in the invention of stereo by EMI engineer Alan Blumlein. The studio doors have been shut to those not recording ever since 1931 .
Alison Saunders' legal adviser was a barrister at 23 Essex Street where Daniel Janner worked. Crown Prosecution Service confirmed it consulted Neil Moore over whether to prosecute Lord Janner. Senior police officers probing allegations of child abuse offences have reportedly raised concerns about Mr Moore's involvement in decision .
David Rylance, 47, was in charge of an appointee account set up at Lloyds Bank which held his mother's cash. He spent the money on gambling, a holiday and cinema tickets, court heard. He admitted theft and fraud involving £52,000 and was jailed for two years and three months.

The child was found by a passer-by wandering near Milwaukee Avenue and Palatine Road in Prospect Heights, Illinois around 6:30 pm Tuesday . He's jailed in Van Buren County, Michigan, pending extradition to Illinois to face charges of aggravated kidnapping  .
Judy Eddingfield, 65, celebrated her 50th anniversary working at Winstead's restaurant in Kansas City last week and declares that it's the only job's she's ever had or ever wanted. On April, 6, 1965 Eddinngfield began working at the restaurant where she was trained by her mother who had already been employed at the establishment for 13 years. 'It's like my home away from home and I just love it here,' she said. 'I was three years old when my mother started here, so I've been eating these burger 60 some years'
The 17,500 sq ft mansion was built on the site of an old telephone exchange in Chelsea, west London. It is 18 times the size of the average new home, with nine bedrooms, nine bathrooms, a cinema, a Japanese water garden and indoor swimming pool. But the stamp duty alone, paid on top of the price of the home, is enough for the Treasury to pay the annual salary of 330 nurses. It has now been bought by an offshore company for £51,191,950.

A 13-year-old boy allegedly shot and killed a teacher and injured four others at a school in Barcelona this morning. He is said to have targeted his female Catalan teacher and her daughter, also a student at the school. The male substitute teacher was shot dead as he tried to protect the woman and daughter . The boy, who has not been named, is undergoing a psychiatric examination after the attack. He told classmates last week that he was planning to kill all the teachers, but none took him seriously   .
Royal Dutch Shell Plc has filed a complaint in federal court in Alaska seeking an. order to remove Greenpeace activists who climbed aboard an oil. rig in the Pacific Ocean bound for the Arctic on Monday. The environmental group said in a statement its team would occupy the underside of the main deck of the Polar Pioneer,. which is under contract to Shell, and plans to unfurl a banner.
The National Park Service and the Secret Service are recommending the addition of half-inch-thick spikes, angled away from the White House, to the existing fence. The new spikes, officially known as 'pencil protrusions,' will be bolted on at the top for a year or more while an entirely new fence – as tall as 10 feet – is planned and fabricated. The White House might also get a prison-style double fence with space in between, but barbed wire has been ruled out.  .  .
Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust teams has seen the number of encounters increase by 68 per cent over the past 12 years. Common dolphins were once a rare sight in the Hebrides, preferring warmer waters found further south. Experts believe that global warming has led to pods moving north. The shift north could be creating new opportunities for the common dolphins to find food in new areas .

Researchers at the Technical University of Braunschweig, Germany, used peppermint plants, which contain minimal traces of nicotine, in a series of mulching and fumigation experiments. nicotine was frequently used as an insecticide until it was banned by the European Union in 2009. But a surprisingly large number of food crops still contain high levels.

Proposals came after an increase in home fires and blasts linked to homemade hash oil. In Colorado, at least 30 people were injured last year in 32 butane explosions involving hash oil - nearly three times the number reported throughout 2013.

The rare mammal has been making waves at the Taiji Whale Museum in southern Japan. The rare specimen is believed to be only the second one ever put on display in an aquarium. It was captured by fishermen during the annual dolphin hunt in the town of Taiji in January last year after it was purchased from fishermen .

Pamela Anderson joined Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio on Wednesday to promote the benefits of an all-vegetarian diet for prison inmates. Arpaio says cutting meat from the meals served to the more than 8,000 inmates has saved an estimated $200,000 per year. The jail has been serving vegetarian meals for 16 months now. Inmates, who receive just two meals a day, have previously called the food 'slop'
Lucy is the oldest and most complete fossil of an early human ever found. Discovered in 1974, the 3.2 million-year-old skeleton stunned archaeologists who unearthed the fossil while digging in an isolated spot in Ethiopia.
Modular Robotic Vehicle, or MRV, developed at NASA's Johnson Space Center to show off technologies that could let man move across other planets. Can park sideways, spin on the spot, and be driven remotely at 70mph .
Thousands of blue jellyfish-like creatures are washing up on beaches across Oregon, California and Washington this spring. They have a small blue sail on top of their bodies which means they are easily blown to shore by strong winds. The creatures are not harmful to humans but will begin to smell fishy as they start to decompose. They are also known as 'by-the-wind sailors' or purple sails.
Janet Brown, 51, was found dead at her family home in Radnage, Buckinghamshire, in 1995. Mother-of-three's naked body was found at the bottom of the stairs by builders doing work on the house. She had been beaten to death with a blunt instrument like a crowbar and was gagged with packing tape. Detectives believe forensics experts now have the suspect's DNA  .

Swedish scientists analysed 10,000 families with children aged two to 14 who did not have type 1 diabetes. They looked at whether there was any family conflict, a change of family structure, interventions from social services or unemployment. Subsequently, 58 children were diagnosed with the condition .

Firefighters were called to the site northeast of Greeley airport shortly after 1 p.m. Friday. The fire began when lightning struck a water storage tank, launching it into the air. The water contained traces of hydrocarbons and petroleum as a result of hydraulic fracturing, which ignited. The tanker was near an injection well where fracking wastewater is pumped into the ground. Nearby homes were evacuated, but no injuries were reported. The Academy of Country Music’s Party for a Cause festival at Globe Life Park in Arlington was threatened Saturday night .

Little Zane Gbangbola died at home – in the middle of the night – after being poisoned by gas. For months after his death, police and other official agencies ruled out fears the deadly fumes had come from a landfill site. Instead, they insisted carbon monoxide from a faulty pump hired by his family had caused his death. But damning new evidence proves the authorities knew for 14 months that hydrogen cyanide gas had leaked into the family's home. The Mail on Sunday has seen leaked statements from police interviews with senior firefighters who were among the first on the scene when Zane was rushed to hospital. The documents also revealed no traces of carbon mon CO had been detected at the home in Chertsey, Surrey. Local residents have accused the authorities of lying and putting lives at risk over the tragedy .

Nasa's Landsat 7 satellite captured the image of the Erg Chech, a desolate sand sea in southwestern Algeria. It shows 'ribbons' of sand and patterned stripes known as linear dunes in the desert. Linear dunes are straight ridges of sand that have been known to measure as long as 99 miles (160km) But the exact cause of these longitudinal structures is not known, and the wind movement is disputed .

The US attorney's office, who released the affidavit, declined to prosecute, and the FBI has not revealed what they found in the storage facility.

Tidal's $19.99-a-month app launched in New York on 30 March. Following the launch the app jumped to 4th place on the iOS music chart. It now ranks at 51 in the music category and 872 in the overall download chart in the US. In the UK the situation is worse, with the app ranking at 92 in the Music app category. By comparison, Pandora radio and Spotify occupy first and second spots respectively when the iOS and Google Play downloads are combined. It is not known why the app has dropped so significantly but the price may be considered too high for some users who downloaded it during the trial period .

Scientists at the University of Reading say chewing gum helps you forget a song. In a study people were less likely to think about it when chewing. And they were a third more likely to 'hear' the song when chewing gum. The results suggests same technique could stop other intrusive thoughts. The study is the first to examine the effects of chewing gum on earworms .

Neanderthals may have died out because they were unable to get as much energy from their food as modern humans who used fire. Archaeologists at Boston University and the University of Bath believe this would have meant they lost out when modern humans arrived from Africa. Without fire, a group of Neanderthals would have had less energy than humans.

SwiftKey analysed more than one billion sets of emoji data to learn how 16 different languages and regions use emoji. Happy faces, including winks, kisses, smiles and grins were the most popular across all regions, making up 45 per cent of all the messages studied. Sad faces were in second place followed by hearts, which includes all colours of hearts and the broken heart emoji. Hand gestures such as thumbs up, clapping hands and the peace were in fourth, followed by romantic emoji, such as the lipstick kiss mark, love letter and couple kissing. The French use them the least .

They claim he believes there is 'scientific evidence' to back his claims. The Victorian Registration and Qualifications Authority is currently investigating the allegations.
The NFL expects 6,000 of nearly 20,000 retired players to suffer from Alzheimer's disease or dementia someday. The settlement approved on Wednesday by a federal judge in Philadelphia would pay them about $190,000 on average. Settlement also includes allowing for monetary awards of up to $5million per claimant for serious medical conditions associated with repeated head trauma. About 200 NFL retirees or their families have rejected the settlement.
£2.99 app is designed to help you edit your portrait photographs into 'perfection' Can remove spots, improve skin texture and enhance eyes. Can also fix grey hair, reshape your face and even fill in bald patches .
Austin Hatfield, 18, found the venomous water moccasin, also known as a cottonmouth, near his Wimauma home last week. He'd been keeping the serpent in a pillowcase when it escaped over the weekend. Bites from the cottonmouth are known to cause extreme swelling and can lead to death.
Lucas Hinch, who runs an organic herb and tea shop, was cited for discharging a firearm within city limits after officers responded to a 'shots fired' call early on Monday evening. A judge will decide what penalty the citation carries, and Hinch is good-natured.
Sid Ahmed Ghlam, 24, shot himself in the leg before his arrest by anti-terrorist officers in Paris. Police found Arabic documents mentioning ISIS and Al Qaeda at IT student's home. Also found evidence he was in contact with a man in Syria 'who asked him to target a church' . Arrest came just hours after murder of Aurelie Chatelain, 33, in Paris suburb of Villejuif. Mother and fitness instructor was shot dead as she sat in her car in car park on Sunday morning. Investigators reportedly claim DNA evidence links him to her murder  .
Five-year-old Iranian girl has spent more than a year in Nauru detention centre. She has self-harmed by swallowing shampoo and nails and has been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. Lawyers are fighting to stop the girl being sent back to the island.
Human traffickers run huge benefit frauds in UK, including one used to fund housing development in Slovakia. The vile trade also includes the sale of young girls for prostitution and sham marriages. In some cases, 'customers' from outside the EU are requesting women with EU passports so they can make them pregnant. The migrants then claim they have a human right to a family life in the UK to raise the child, the report says .
Seven of the costumes from the 1965 classic, along with a VHS cassette tape of the film signed by actor Dan Truitt, are expected to fetch $800,000 when they are auctioned off at Nate D. Sanders on April 30. The costumes are being auctioned as one single lot at the auctioneer's website.
Samantha Rawcliffe, 40, suddenly lost all control of her body and crashed her car last May. In the days after the accident she was shaking uncontrollably and wet herself repeatedly. She blamed the shaking on her shock and thought she had a trapped nerve. Tests revealed she was suffering functional neurological disorder, an umbrella term for a variety of neurological symptoms that doctors cannot explain. Mrs Rawcliffe is now confined to her home, unable to walk and relies on a mobility scooter. She has to take 32 tablets each day to treat symptoms.
State-controlled Gazprom is a vital supplier of energy to. Europe despite the EU's frequent political disputes with Moscow. EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager said Gazprom was barring EU clients from selling on its gas to other.
Noaa Fisheries in Maryland says the humpback whale is no longer endangered. They want to break up global population into 14 sub-populations. Ten of these will be 'not at risk', two 'threatened' and two 'endangered' It follows a conservation 'success story' that raised numbers to 90,000. Some experts warn it is too soon.
Ricky Woolaston, 35, posed as a university maintenance engineer to gain access to students' homes. He would steal laptops and mobile phones to feed his drug habit but was caught when he left behind a police charge sheet. He has now been sentenced to four years in prison for five burglaries.
For the first time ever, fans can see a detailed breakdown of how support for every club varies around the world. The map was created by looking at the official Twitter accounts for each team, using their followers as an indicator of allegiance. Arsenal are the most popular team with 5.6million followers, followed by Chelsea (5.4m) and Manchester United (4.8m) across the globe .
Scientists in Belgium say all sweet potatoes contain 'foreign DNA' Agrobacterium bacteria in the crop exchanges genes between species. This makes sweet potatoes a 'natural genetically modified organism' And humans have been eating it for thousands of years. The remarkable finding of ‘foreign DNA’ in the vegetable shows that it contains a type of natural genetically modified organisms (GMO) The research was conducted by scientists from Ghent University in Belgium and the International Potato Institute.
Gregg Manderson, 68, of St Paul, Minnesota, first sought medical help after he got Twinkle Twinkle Little Star stuck in his head last May. He has also hallucinated the theme song to the 1950s television show Cheyenne. Dr Khalaf Alla Bushara and Roger Dumas of the Minneapolis VA Medical Center are trying to cure.

The 17-year-old had been studying film, performance, English and sociology at Shrewsbury Sixth Form College. Her mother Elizabeth said her daughter was a talented singer who dreamed of becoming an actress. Friends have paid tribute to Miss Blakeway .

'Mrs. Clinton, when are you going to start talking to the press about Benghazi?' Daily Mail Online asked her. Officers noticed that he had a bloody lip and smelled of alcohol, but he refused to perform a breath test and so officers got a search warrant to take a blood sample  .

They were dropped off in the Sicilian port of Augusta after their smuggler boat was picked up off the Italian mainland. Fiona White was stunned to find the pictures while looking at others he had taken of colleagues. Valentine admitted ten allegations of taking photographs without medical reason or consent.

Noise-induced hearing loss is one of the most common work-related illnesses. Scientists have identified a gene, named Nox3, found in the inner ear, that is crucial in determining how vulnerable a person is.

University of Illinois scientists have created the first 3D simulation of merging black holes in a disk. It shows what happens when two supermassive black holes collide. Material swirls around the objects in a quasar and jets fire out from the poles in the merger. It comes after two black holes were found to be seven years away from merging. The simulation could provide an insight into what will happen if - or when - they merge in the future .
The UCO Stormproof Matches are made using an incredibly tough coating that smoulders no matter what happens to them. The matches have to go through rigorous testing to make sure they keep alight in even the most difficult situations. They can also keep smouldering even while underwater .
Palaeontologists say male stegosaurus could have used them to show off their prowess in much the same way as peacocks do today. They say the key differences between the sexes lie in bones near the base of the tail. It raises the prospect that the dinosaurs used its giant bony protrusions to attract a mate to a mate.

Yom Hazikaron - or Memorial Day - is held the day before Israel's independence day. It links the sacrifice of soldiers with the creation and protection of the state. Under law all places of entertainment, including cinemas, are closed by law on the day. Many Israelis attend memorial services for relatives and friends who died.
Papyrus found in Oxyrhynchus, Egypt, contains a medical 'recipe' for treating a hangover. It recommends stringing the leaves of a shrub called Alexandrian chamaedaphne together and wearing it around the neck to relieve headaches .

The James Webb Space Telescope will be 100 times more potent than Hubble. It will be able to see back to 200 million years after the Big Bang. JWST's main mirror will be 21ft (6.5 metres) in diameter, three times as large as Hubble's. Infra-red capability will help it observe distant celestial bodies, and its camera shutter will remain open for long periods.

The 1962 Aston Martin DB4 Series III will be worth three times its £220,000 price if fully restored. The British vehicle was supplied new in July 1961 to a Robert Drummond of London in SW1. Gaydos knew he was being pursued but drove off because he was driving on a suspended license. Troopers followed him for nearly 40 miles at speeds of 130 mph before Martinez pulled alongside him and fired four times through the window of his moving car, striking him once in the thigh. Martinez was ultimately suspended for three days without pay .
The underwear is adorned with beads and would have been sewn together by a woman using strips of seal pelt. It is currently on display at the National Museum of Denmark in Copenhagen as part of its animal-skin clothing collection. It was obtained during an expedition to the Ammassalik settlement in Greenland in 1892 by Captain C. Ryder. The naatsit was the only undergarment the Inuit would have worn next to their bare skin   .

Charlesetta Taylor, 79, has lived in her home in St. Louis for 70 years, and was part of the first African-American family to live in the neighborhood. Now the city may tear down her home and 49 others to make way for a campus for the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. The NGA creates maps and satellite imagery that is used by the military for national security, among other things. If residents are not willing to move, the city says it will use eminent domain to take their homes. A Change.org petition has been started and already has over 90,000 signatures.
Oskar Groening is being tried on 300,000 counts of accessory to murder for his role at Auschwitz. He was on duty between May and July 1944 when 425,000 Jews from Hungary were brought to the camp. During that period, so many trains were arriving that often two would have to wait with closed doors as the first was 'processed' Auschwitz survivors describe their arrival as chaotic, with Nazi guards yelling orders, dogs barking and families ripped apart.

Fire boat Massey Shaw was requisitioned from the London Fire Brigade in 1940 and transported to Dunkirk to help with the evacuation of Allied troops in the face of the Nazi advance. After carrying 600 soldiers back to Britain, the boat returned to London where it helped to save St Paul's Cathedral and other buildings damaged in the Blitz. The boat went out of service in 1971 and was used as a walkway in a London dock. It took six years to restore it to its former glory thanks to a National Lottery grant.

Kate Roberts, 24, noticed her son Miles had a slightly different shaped head when he was born. At three months, he was diagnosed with flat head syndrome, also known as 'flat head syndrome' This is when the back of the head becomes flattened, causing the head to widen and the front of the skull to bulge out. It is thought to be caused by babies sleeping on their back and is not medically dangerous. NHS does not pay for treatment as it is a cosmetic, rather than medical problem.

Major General Allen Batschelet says that 10 percent of young men and women who sign up to join the Army are currently refused because they are too heavy. He warns that by 2020 as many as half of young Americans will be so grossly overweight by the end of the decade that the military will be unable to recruit enough qualified soldiers. The maximum body fat percentage that the Army allows for recruits aged 17-20 is 20 percent for men and 30 percent for females. Obesity rates have tripled in a generation with more than one-third of U.S. adults.

The Australian Air Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) released its report on Wednesday into the 'wheels up landing' on December 12, 2014 at Jabiru Airport, southeast of Darwin. The unidentified pilot was flying a six-seat Cessna 310 aircraft, registered VH-TBE, with two adults and three children on board when he became distracted by one of the passengers. The report also found the pilot was 'relatively new to the C-310' and unfamiliar with the plane equipment. There were no injuries to either the pilot or passengers but the aircraft was 'substantially damaged' and the plane was damaged, the report found.

Second eruption from Calbuco volcano in southern Chile has covered towns and villages in thick layer of ash. First eruption in over four decades yesterday sent vast clouds of dust more than six miles into the air. Another unexpected eruption in the Los Lagos Region today heightened fears of local waters becoming contaminated. The ash covered cars and houses in cities as far as 18 miles away from the source of the eruption as another massive evacuation effort gets underway. Previous and equally violent eruptions have continued for up to a week, according to volcanologist.

Bikram yoga involves 26 poses performed in a room heated to 40°C (105°F) with 40 per cent humidity. Scientists at the University of Wisconsin-La Crosse have warned the practice raises the risk of heat stroke. A typical 90-minute class is reduced to just an hour to reduce the risk. Scientists advise shortening the length of the class to just one hour to minimise the risk .

Photographers captured some remarkable pictures of the Lyrid meteor shower above the UK last night. The meteor shower, visible around the world but best seen from Europe, peaked overnight with between ten and 20 meteors an hour. Nick Watson, a semi-professional photographer from Newcastle, captured an amazing picture of the meteor over Lindisfarne Castle on Holy Island in Northumberland. He took his photo around 1am BST this morning and incredibly managed to get the colourful Northern Lights in the picture too. The cosmic show will continue on into Saturday, so it is still possible to catch some meteors.

Willa Junior says he was exhausted and dozed off while loading a plane at Seattle-Tacoma Airport on April 13. He woke up when a piece of luggage landed on his head and then called 911 - but his call cut out after 44 seconds . He started banging on the ceiling of the cargo hold and passengers and crew heard and the plane was forced to turn around after just 14 minutes in the air . Junior is currently still employed at Menzies Aviation, but he has been permanently banned from working on Alaska Airlines flights. He says he is incredibly sorry for the trouble his nap caused the passengers  .
Security researchers have found a way to intercept a person's fingerprints on a Samsung Galaxy S5 running Android 4.4 and older. When a fingerprint is scanned it is encrypted, but the flaw allows hackers to collect scans from the sensor before being encrypted. The flaw lies in older versions of the Android operating system. Anyone running Android 5.0 or above is not at risk and should update immediately .

The 59-year-old says he will be adding fairy lights to the structure tonight and plans to add an extra two calves to complete the sculpture.

Researchers at the University of Bath and Yale University created the invention. It uses a newly designed molecular catalyst to split water in an electrolyser and create clean and storable hydrogen fuel. The main problem with the production of hydrogen was the waste oxygen it produces. The new catalyst is more efficient at performing the crucial oxidation half of the reaction than any other existing material, minimising energy losses.
